text: All right, welcome back here with Alexey Tolchinsky, a friend and colleague and collaborator on this paper, Temporal Depth in a Coherent Self and in Depersonalization Theoretical Model.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, go for it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Well, I'd like to say hello to everyone and thank you for being with us after such a long and fruitful day at 6 p.m.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: on the East Coast.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is, I appreciate your interest.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And thank you, Daniel.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thank you, Active Inference Institute for this fantastic symposium.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we'll be working, talking today about this paper on dissociative states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And it's a collective effort.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This paper is in peer review right now.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Early preprint was posted on the site.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And it was work by Michael Levin, Chris Fields, Lancelot DaCosta, Rachel Murphy, Daniel, who's here, David Pincus, and myself.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is the link to the paper if you'd like to take a look at the early preprint.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Perhaps some of you would like maybe to get a feel for what we're talking about.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is not a patient's account.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is a poem from Kurt Weill and his song Pretty Pumpkin.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I woke up this morning, didn't recognize the man in the mirror.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Then I laughed and I said, oh, silly me, that's just me.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Then I proceeded to brush some stranger's teeth, but they were my teeth and I was weightless, just quivering like some leaf come in the window of a restroom.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this poem was cited by Paul Molyneux.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: He's a specialist of DID in England on the Psychiatry and Psychotherapy podcast.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You can also find patient's account on YouTube.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I couldn't post the video here for copyright reasons.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So dissociations are a spectrum, and they range from mild to severe, transient to chronic.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They can be benign and pathological, and certainly they're not a bright line category.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The causes vary for them as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We call it etiology in the clinical world.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They can be caused by psychological trauma, neurological conditions, substances, seizures, anesthesia, and different sleep phases.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's a subset of conditions here we call dissociative disorders.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Typically in the history of these patients, we see prolonged elevation of stress accompanied by repeated traumatic experiences in circumstances where they feel there is no escape, typically childhood abuse and neglect.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we call that complex trauma, which has a different presentation than acute trauma.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we'll touch upon why this specific pathway of etiology is important for dissociative disorders.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Well, I'd like to say why this matters.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What's at stake?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What's the motivation for this paper?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we have many authors, and they have variable motivations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But I'm a clinician.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I see patients all day.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And for me, the main reason for that is these conditions are hard to diagnose.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Many patients go undiagnosed for a long time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're very hard to treat.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we're sometimes content with partial results.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the risk of self-harm or suicide is higher for these patients.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And there are many, many reasons for that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We think that perhaps one of the reasons is that there is no unified theory of dissociations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have kind of...
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: neurobiological ideas, the corticolimbic inhibition hypothesis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have psychodynamic ideas.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have attempts to model dissociations from first principles by Anna Sionica and other colleagues.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But these different attempts are not tied together and certainly not tied together with the patient's subjective experiences.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we are trying to make steps in that direction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we don't claim that we've built a unified theory of dissociations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But what we're doing here is we're focusing on one aspect of dissociations, one focal point that is a collapse of the temporal depth in any kind of dissociation, regardless of the cause.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: By temporal depth, we mean how far into the future the person can plan.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What we're hoping for is that this focused approach has the potential to allow us to
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: perhaps develop more accurate diagnostic procedures and to possibly help increase efficacy in therapy with full respect to how difficult, complex, and messy this work is.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Additional point of convergence is we explore multiple theoretical perspectives in the paper, and they all converge on the same point.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Here is the main thesis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: the collapse of the temporal depth is necessary and sufficient for the onset of a dissociative episode.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we're going a little bit further than colleagues who already mentioned a relationship between temporal depth and dissociations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Dean and Anna Syunicka and others and Carl Friston were saying it's causal, that there is no dissociation without the temporal depth collapse, and the collapse of the temporal depth will reliably lead to dissociative episodes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Further, we are saying that temporal depth collapse can be conceptualized as a common pathway for the onset of dissociative symptoms, regardless of etiology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And finally, we suggest that the focus on restoring the temporal depth can be an effective strategy in therapeutic interventions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One of the theoretical perspectives we explored in the paper is Michael Levin's TAME framework, Technological Approach to Mind Everywhere.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: which I think is very useful.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And unfortunately, I haven't seen many attempts to use it in clinical applications.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is the title and the link to the paper.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's so much in Michael Levin's work that is useful.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: His paper on cancer, which is based on his experiments, is also one of the inspirations for our paper here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But here's another inspiration.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you dive into Michael Levin's work, you'll probably see what he claims, based on experiments, that all intelligences are collective intelligences.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: However, at our subjective level, at the level of the conscious mind, we don't feel that way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We perceive unity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: All our percepts, sensations, thoughts, feelings come together in a cohesive and coherent whole, a single conscious experience in the here and now.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we will talk about this seeming paradox, if you wish, in our paper.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Some of the core tenants of the team framework, not all of them, but some,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Key points, commitment to graduality.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There is no bright lines.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Michael suggests that intelligence is built gradually and by accumulation of complexity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Material independence.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Our model is not based on neurons or central nervous system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We will talk certainly about a subset.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You know, I'm a clinician, I work with human beings, so we'll talk about brain-based models, but generally the model applies to synthetic agents and cells that are not neurons.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Commitment to empirical research as opposed to just exchange of opinions on the subject.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Dynamics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The selves are not fixed, they're malleable and plastic.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And selves can be nested and overlapping, cooperating and competing both laterally and across levels.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is an illustration of one of the key concepts in Levin's framework called a light cone.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And what you see here depicted is various organisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the middle of the slide, you see a tick and a dog, a human being, possible AI, compound intelligence such as an ant colony.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you see this sort of nested and embedded structure on the picture on the right.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And Lycon has two dimensions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's a spatial dimension on the horizontal plane, and the vertical dimension is temporal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And tick, for example, is not particularly concerned with things happening a mile away.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It cannot recall far from the past and plan far into the future.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: While human beings are capable of planning things that happen after we die, a living will.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And with the use of language and culture and books, we can use things that happened before we were born.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we're capable of huge light cones.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I'm highlighting this word capable of.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It doesn't mean that in our wakeful hours, alert hours, we are walking around with a significant light cone.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they contract and expand depending on various circumstances, but we're certainly capable of them, well, ticks or not.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The vertical dimension of a light cone is exactly what we mentioned before.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That is the temporal depth.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There is, of course, a perspective on the same thing in FEPP, and I like this very succinct
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: phrased by Carl Friston, who said, because consequences follow causes, the generative model acquires a temporal depth.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And more formally, some agents are only capable of modeling their immediate environment and live in the here and now, while others are capable of planning actions into the future.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the generative models capable of planning are referred to as temporally deep generative models.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So temporal depth under FEPP is the length of the temporal horizon that is considered during planning.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're moving on to describing the, if you wish, healthy self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we do mention that it is a materially independent structure where, you know, in principle, we can talk about the cells of synthetic agents and, you know, cell collectives.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Cells depend on an organism's ability to infer.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And here we will provide a few points on the two clinical terms familiar to clinicians, such as derealization and depersonalization.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the organism's beliefs about the world are the inferences about the external environment, and the continuum of issues in this process we will call derealization.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: While the organism's beliefs about its own internal milieu, its body and mind, we will call the self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the continuum of issues of this process we will call depersonalization.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The selves are a hierarchical composite nested in with boundaries.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we consider a self to be a system consisting of hierarchically structured beliefs, which effectively makes it a dynamic hierarchical generative model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And taken in its entirety, the self is informationally separated from the external environment by a Markov blanket or a near Markov blanket by a boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We'd like to emphasize, I apologize if this is trivial to the audience of the Active Inference Institute,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that this boundary is not material like skin, it is informational, through which the self and not-self interact.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So to emphasize, the self, as we have defined it, is a model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It is not an organism.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The organism constructs and implements it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the self is quite literally the construction of the mind.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is an illustration of that from early work by Michael Levin.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I think this was his doctoral dissertation materials.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And what you see here is duck embryos.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that started from an oocyte, and then you have blastoderm.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: After cell division, you have a collection of cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And at the top left, if nothing is done, then this blastoderm will develop into a single ducky.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You see this green, shrimpy-looking thing?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's a single duck.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: However, if you introduce a scratch in this blastoderm and the wound heals, the same exact cell collective may develop into twins or triplets.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You see the red, yellow, and green duckies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now think about that for a moment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What happened here?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This collective of cells computed what is me and what is not me.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the hardware did not change.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But in one case, it made a decision that this is all me and the rest of it is not me.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And another one, it says there's three me's.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you can see that this is not hardware.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Cells are also, as I mentioned, hierarchical, composite, nested, and they have boundaries.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So now we're moving on to components of the self that are, each component is separated by their own boundary and mark of blanket.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And because we're using the word hierarchical, we will define that there is a core self, a core component.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you'd like a visual metaphor that Mark Solms uses, we can think about an onion, and there's different layers of the onion, and there's a core in the middle.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We will talk about that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: as applied to humans and mammals and rodents, so now we are in organisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This term is from Effective Neuroscience, from Jaak Panksepp and Lucy Bivens' book, and also, you know, I believe Solms and Turnbull used it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, core self is non-reflexive and dominated by raw feelings and part of purely effective core form of consciousness.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the effective homeostatic mechanisms allow an animal to problem-solve in novel environments.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I'll give you an illustration from Mark Solms to maybe just bring it home.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Imagine that I'm in the room full of carbon monoxide, and I've never been in that before.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I don't really know what to do, but I feel badly.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I feel badly in a very specific way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's air hunger, suffocation distress.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And let's say I'm moving around the room,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But if I move to the left and I feel a little bit better, then that's information.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if I move to the right and I feel worse, that's also information.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Perhaps there's a door on the left and there's a draft underneath the door and I feel better.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this compass, this internal mechanism, the homeostatic mechanism, allowed me to find out a possible solution.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we have a whole collection of these to mention, you know, the actual hunger for food and thirst and
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: social homeostats such as rage and fear and panic, separation, distress, etc.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the collection of that is what Panksepp and Soames conceptualize as the core self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Therefore, the set of predictions in the core self that all the life-sustaining affects will be at or near their settling points, which means, in emotional terms, contentment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: All my needs are met.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I am a-okay, thank you very much, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that is the minimum of the variational free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If there are deviations from it, such as hunger or thirst or air hunger, then that would be a prediction error accompanied by a negative feeling, like in the example that I used above.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In mammals, we're not putting an equal sign, but we're describing the anatomical structures that are participating in serving this function.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're talking about the upper brainstem regions, including the reticular activating system and the periaqueductal gray.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They mediate the functioning of the core self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you can see a lot more details in Mark's book, Hidden Spring, A Journey to the Source of Consciousness.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, poor self is thought to be present in animals without the cortex, such as decorticated cats, that are actually more effective, and not less.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the cases of human children born without a cortex, hydrancephalic children, they have emotions when, you know, they
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: put a brother on the girl's chest, she smiles and she cries.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the core self does not require a functional neocortex.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The higher levels of the brain structures in humans, including the cortex, mediate the higher levels of both consciousness and the self, and sometimes it's referred to as extended consciousness, which allows us to reflect on what's going on, such as to say, I feel anxious right now.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There isn't a symmetry in this
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: model where the higher levels, the peripheral levels of the self and consciousness cannot exist without the core.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: While the reverse is not true, the core can exist without the higher levels.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One of the other illustrations of that which Solemn cites, this is based on Fisher's work in 2016, is that a tiny lesion, a two cubic millimeter lesion in a periberical nucleus will reliably and irreversibly reduce a coma
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: the patient will never become conscious ever again, while you will never have anything like that happen in the cortex.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You know, this small lesion in the cortex will not result in catastrophic outcomes like that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is one of the reasons why neurosurgeons don't usually like to operate around the brainstem.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is too consequential, too risky.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So everything we said about consciousness, the core and extended, is applied to self as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The peripheral self components cannot function without the operational core self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we will illustrate that with specific examples in humans later on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In addition to this on-off, where the thing is completely operational or not,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can talk about the influence, and the core self has the ability to change the regime of functioning in other more peripheral self components by inducing phase transitions in them, and the brain mechanism for that is generalized arousal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: When the higher levels of consciousness are present and functional, then we have representations such as fruit and vegetables, and in the core self we have raw affects such as separation distress or anger,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: but with the higher levels of consciousness presence, we are capable of thinking things like, I want an apple, or the affect, the drive, as in Freudian language and in Psalms language, is attached to the object.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And similarly, we can have these constructions about the meta objects, such as I, such as I look pale, or I am a pessimist, and I here is a mental object.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And therefore, I is a metacognitive construct, an abstraction, and it only exists at the higher levels of the self, such as autobiographical self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It is not used or even needed in the core self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To reiterate, core self as a system has the capacity to detect the effective prediction errors and attempt to minimize the variational free energy through action without any I.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're moving on to peripheral self components, and we'll describe only a few.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the terminology here is different from what you may read in a wonderful book by Anil Seth, Being You.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the first one is autobiographical self, and that's a system dynamically representing our life's history.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you, for example, remember your 10th birthday, and the cake is on the table, and mom is there, and your friends are there, and the sun is shining, and everyone's smiling, and it's Tuesday, that's an episode.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's an episodic memory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And a collection of them, organized through time, is our sort of life narrative.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There is a bodily self, which is a system dynamically building inferences about our body and various representations and interoceptive processing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's a social self, which is a system representing inferences about how we're seen by others and how we present ourselves and act in the social environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Each peripheral self component, such as bodily self, for example, has its own mark of blanket, and each component is embedded into the whole self and also contains sub-components, creating a nested architecture that you saw in the tamed light cone picture before.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: About the unity, that in humans, at the higher levels of the self, such as at the autobiographical self level, these levels create an impression of a unified experience,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is just the experience of the autobiographical self, not the entire system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The autobiographical self claims to itself and others to be the entire self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Well, it is not.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So Anil Seth refers to these things as delusion.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have a delusion of being a unified .
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But what we're saying is that it is that system that is deluded, the autobiographical self subsystem.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm ambivalent about using the term diluted.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I think it's not the optimal one because we use it in the clinical world, and I prefer it called inference or belief that we're unified.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Stated differently, we can say that a stable belief that I'm whole, I'm complete in the autobiographical self, its generative model contributes to us feeling as a monadic self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Therefore, the subjectively perceived unity, the coherence of the self, is an inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Related to coherence, another thing we can talk about is continuity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And nearly as a tautology, stemming from the definition of Markov blanket, our self remain the same, persist in time, while all the processes or communications across its Markov blanket remain functional.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we can offer you another viewpoint on the same exact phenomenon from, if you wish, more neurobiological perspective, psychological perspective.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you recall, maybe you're at the train station or, you know, anywhere in the city and you see someone and you think you recognize them, but you're not sure, you know, this sensation of recognition of familiar.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the familiarity novelty calculations is what we're talking about here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And depersonalization is a breakdown of that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Something that is familiar, myself, suddenly abruptly becomes very novel and not recognized.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But actually, these calculations neurobiologically are not bright-line dichotomous categories.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They are probabilistic and they are spectrum, but we coarse-grain them in the mind often into yes or no, familiar or novel.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that subjective impression of yes, I know this person or not is just the coarse-graining of the continuous variable.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Representational capacity is important.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The deep generative model implies that the agent is capable of planning into the future, which in turn requires an ability to generate, store, and retrieve counterfactual data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Generate, store, and retrieve is memory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So therefore, when the representational capacity is completely or partially impaired for any reason, the agent completely or partially loses an ability to infer, leading to depersonalization and derealization.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If we talk about health and pathology briefly, the two key terms here are voluntary and involuntary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You know, again, all of us during our day, we can either sit down to plan things, you know, for, you know, 10 year temporal horizon, which expands our temporal depth, or when we meditate or rock climb, you know, then we can be more in the moment in the here and now.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But trauma doesn't ask permission.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I mean, perpetrators are, you know,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: there's nothing voluntary about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so that's an involuntary collapse of the temporal depth, which usually is leading to pathological conditions.

text: This is a perspective from the nonlinear dynamical systems.

text: If, again, I am in adult, healthy, alert functioning, and I may have small deviations from I and me, say I'm daydreaming or something like that, then the collection of these points from which I reliably return to I and me

text: can be described as the attractor basin.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the whole thing in terms of attractor landscape is the setpoint attractor regime, IME.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And IME would be the variational free energy minimum.

text: There may be multiple post-traumatic presentations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And one of the possible options is depicted here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is not, again, universal, but it's one of the possible options.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What you see here is a multiple coexisting point attractors represented by local minima of the variational free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they can correspond to alters in DID.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And in this example, you also see that they're surrounded by a global minimum of variational free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, also, if you look at the area, the region between the local minima, then in dynamical systems, that's called a repeller, and repellers are notoriously chaotic, so that suggests that you may not have very good predictability of how you will transition from ultra-x to ultra-y or ultra-z.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To say a few more words about this, when we switch between the alters,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: then we are in a regime of itinerancy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is the term Carl Friston likes to use a lot and, you know, justifiably so.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Also, when we have these transitions from X, ultra X to Y, that the time is disrupted.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You know, in DID, you don't have this flowing continuity of time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's a series of disruptions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Effectively, then, your coherent large light cone is broken into pieces here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now imagine that this patient with this condition reached out for help and they want to get better.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But this attractive landscape already acquired some stability.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so again, we need some interference to destabilize the pathological regime.

text: The difference here would be that in therapy, in the process of healing, this destabilization of the pathological attractive landscape is voluntary, controlled and guided, ideally by a licensed and competent
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: mental health professional, and that's the difference from the onset of acute trauma.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So psychotherapy can be one such intervention, and it's the treatment of choice.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have very limited advocacy with medications, and now it's very kind of fashionable to talk about augmentation with psychedelic treatment or perhaps neurostimulation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's important to say that just destabilizing that landscape doesn't guarantee anything at all.

text: So when people present this idea that you just go to, I don't know, and have some ayahuasca or anything, ketamine infusion, and you're better, it's a myth.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Because the important part is that the patient settles back into health, and just the destabilization of this landscape doesn't lead to that.

text: And that therapeutic process when you destabilize the pathological attractive landscape is another phase transition, temporarily chaotic, with the idea that eventually it leads you to a healthier functioning, either a attractive landscape corresponding to cohesive system, or at least a little more coherent system with less alters, partial improvement.

text: Let's talk a little bit more about the phase transition.

text: So before things happen in health, we have a nested and embedded self, and that can be described in FEPP as a hierarchy of coupled interconnected attractors.

text: Carl Friston wrote that slower attractor can possibly control the phase transition of the faster attractor.

text: And in our system, the core self is feeling-based, it's affective, and it's one of the components of affects of feelings is generalized arousal.

text: It's an effective storm.

text: It's a flood of cortisol that is abrupt and severe.

text: and that abrupt increase in generalized arousal leading to the destabilization of a healthy attractor landscape in the autobiographical self.

text: A few clinical observations, starting from dissociative disorders, which are conceptualized traditionally as defensive response to prolonged and inescapable trauma.

text: Clinicians talk about, and patients report, this quality of emotional flatness or deadness or numbing.

text: Sometimes they call it freeze.

text: So in our model, it corresponds to issues with communications between the core self and the peripheral self components.

text: And in FEPP terms, that means lowering of precision associated with affective prediction error messages.

text: We're moving on to also severe dissociations, but temporary, such as general anesthesia, propofol.

text: And it's a very profound change in the body that influences the gap junctions between the cells.

text: And recovery from anesthesia is a very interesting process.

text: Michael Levin is fascinated with it.

text: It's actually a little bit of a miracle that we come back to be the same person we have been before.

text: And some people don't.

text: You may wake up a pirate.

text: And these conditions are called post-operative delirium, dissociative amnesia, post-operative cognitive dysfunction.

text: This is also an illustration that self is computed and plastic and malleable.

text: It's not a hardware.

text: And perhaps we get oriented with the use of our memory systems, including the episodic memories.

text: There is no past and no future beyond that.

text: A neurobiological perspective briefly.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The historically most famous one is corticolimbic inhibition hypothesis by Sierra and Berius, who postulated that prefrontal cortex is inhibiting the limbic structures, including the amygdala and the anterior cingulate cortex, ACC.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The subsequent studies don't fully support that hypothesis, but partially support it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I like the work by Ruth Lanius and her colleagues,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And guess what?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Her revision, her refinement of the corticolimbic inhibition adds dynamics, transience, context, and itinerancy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: All the things we like.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They talk about two regimes, even in patients with dissociative syndromes, overmodulation and undermodulation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Again, itinerancy in not one regime, but multiple regimes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Overmodulation is indeed hypoactive amygdala and hyperactive prefrontal cortex, which is described above, but also these patients less frequently, but you can see it in a reverse regime where amygdala is active and PFC is less active.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Overmodulation dominates in dissociative conditions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They refined the anatomical network and talked about different subregions of amygdala, the central medial amygdala, basolateral amygdala, dorsolateral periaqueductal gray, ventral lateral periaqueductal gray, thalamus, and other regions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this network of regions collectively works to create specific posttraumatic regimes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They also described that regime where a patient has access to painful memories usually is accompanied by undermodulation, very active state with amygdala active, and when they don't have access to painful memories, they're more in a dissociative state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can also briefly talk about what are the anatomical substrates and the neuropsychological substrates of the temporal depth collapse.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And again, acute trauma, hippocampal damage, and dementia affect the episodic memory system.
